caption: We love coming to this park. There are always dogs here no matter what time you go. I love running near this place and stopping to watch them. My dog likes it here too. I would advise anyone that comes here to be careful and keep an eye on their dog at all times as a dog was stolen from here ( they got it back eventually after a very long search by the family) so always keep an eye on your own dog.
Incredible Panasonic views of Paris! So happy I ventured over here. The church was very impressive too.  Be forewarned ‚Äî the climb up the stairs is deceptively steep!

Love locks ‚Äî a modern 'tradition' whereby sweethearts inscribe their names or initials on a padlock, attach it to a public structure, and throw away the key, permanently sealing their love . Very nice view also

The Eiffel Tower is deliberately, I learned, impossible to see from Sacred Heart. So, square Nadar is the place to go! Be aware that this is a small dog park and it is smelly. Go to the fence across the street!

While Sacre-Coeur sits atop the highest spot in the city, you can't actually see the Eiffel Tower while you are in front of it.  However, if you make a short walk around the hill to the little park, there are several benches and shady spots that you can stop for a break and enjoy a view of the Tower.  Definitely worth a stop while touring the hill.
Nice place. Worth a visit. Nice view from the top of Paris.
A nice little dog park with a beautiful view over the city right next to the Sacr√© Coeur.
Stop here to admire the panorama of the city with the Eiffel Tower. Wait for the sunset. Enjoy the moment!

If you want a view of the Eiffel Tower from Montmartre, this is where you can see it. It‚Äôs far from the crowds of the basilica, and a little quiet here. The only bad thing is, there‚Äôs really nowhere to sit (the park has no benches, and it‚Äôs kinda unsanitary, with rats scurrying all over the place). But this has the best view without the crowds.
Doggy paradiseüê∂ with a view of Eiffel Tower ü¶ß ‚Ä¶
Great for a nice quiet sit on a bench. Catch a glimpse of the Eiffel tower while you're there.
A quiet and nice small square away from the crowded places near Sacr√©-C≈ìur with benches for a short rest . A beautiful overlooking view over Paris and Eiffel Tower especially during sunset!
One of the best views of Paris. Great vibe.
Beautiful dog park (small but fun)
A beautiful and scenic park to take your dog and enjoy the atmosphere.
Beautiful view, smelly and small dog park
Beautiful breathtaking place with a view on the whole city
A nice place to take a short break until we complete the rest of the tour program
Great little dog park with amazing view
Nice doggy parc with a beautiful view!
Excellent for a small rest, but as with the rest of paris it looks a bit grimy.
Best dog park in Paris !
Loved it
Nice view
Nice picture spot

Small but well organized. There is a huge lack of caniparks in the 18th arrondissement despite a large population. The squares are invaded by drug addicts and alcoholics who soil and defecate in the bushes but that shocks no one whereas the sight of a dog, which balances a household, if he dares to show off! What horror and everyone is crying scandal!

A square reserved for dogs in the heart of Montmartre, right next to the Sacr√© C≈ìur.  A place where dogs meet and play together and can be let loose.  There is a very nice view of the Sacr√© C≈ìur and Paris.  This Square is pleasant with its sunny exposure.  It's a good thing to have places reserved for dogs in the heart of Paris.  However, there is a lack of green spaces to make it more pleasant for them, but hey, it's complicated given the situation.  There is a statue representing the knight Jean-Fran√ßois de la Barre, beheaded and burned in 1766 for not having greeted a religious procession.

This is one of the recommended spots where you can get a panoramic view of the city. Although it is a tourist spot, there weren't that many people compared to other spots, and I felt that there were a lot of locals.  I went in the evening, and it was a very beautiful place where you could see the city before the sun went down, and the night view after the sun went down.  Tourists can only enter a part of the church, but you can take a tour.  Everyone sat on the steps in front of the association, chatting, drinking, playing music, and having fun as they pleased.  The road from the station to the church is lined with souvenir shops. I think it's an easy spot to get to since it's not that far from the station. There are a few stairs, but if you have some time left in the evening after sightseeing, we recommend that you give it a try!

Butte Montmartre dog area. Access to water.  Recently renovated üíõ Great place to finally take your dog off the leash and let him play freely üòÅ All in a pretty setting and with a great view of Paris, top! ‚Ä¶

A nice place for a short break, there are not many tourists here. At the back of the park there is one of the wells from which you can pour water into a bottle for free, the quality of which is similar to that of water in stores. There are quite a lot of similar wells, but sometimes they are difficult to find.

Very small square right next to the Sacr√©-Coeur basilica, a quiet place where you can relax far from the usual hubbub of the Place du Tertre, currently empty of people given the context. There you can see a small dovecote and the statue in homage to the Chevalier de la Barre.
Even if you don't have a dog, you still go to see dogs at the playground.
Perfect place to rediscover the taste for life! Seeing dogs having fun and the view of the Eiffel Tower / Paris is the best combo! I strongly recommend
Dogs are playing hide and seek and they ALL look chic. People crowd up high to watch this spectacle. Don't shy away from the many steps to access this paradise, you won't come back unscathed!

Open to dogs on a leash.  A small square open 24/7 with a beautiful view of the Eiffel Tower  Located on the Butte Montmartre, near the Sacr√©-C≈ìur basilica, the square pays homage to F√©lix Toumachon (1820-1910), known as Nadar, a pioneer of photography. A statue represents the knight Jean-Fran√ßois de la Barre, beheaded and burned in 1766 for not having greeted a religious procession. A wall indicates the presence of the Montmartre reservoirs, built in the neo-Bysantine style of the Sacr√©-C≈ìur. There are sophoras, oaks and Judas trees.
Great dog park a stone's throw from the Montmartre basilica. Respectful and pleasant owners with adorable dogs.
